node.title: How to Nurture Kindness in a New Generation
node.description: In “Social Justice Parenting,” Traci Baxley emphasizes the rewards of teaching our children to empathize with and care for others.
node.content: ["The holidays will soon be upon us. What is likely to make you feel better \u2014 receiving a gift, or giving one to someone in need? Research is clear that, as the proverb goes, it\u2019s better to give than to receive.", "\u201cDoing kind things makes you feel better,\u201d said Andrew Miles, a sociologist at the University of Toronto. \u201cIt fulfills a basic psychological need, like giving our bodies appropriate food. It helps you feel like your life is valuable.\u201d", "Dr. Miles is currently leading a large, controlled study aiming to quantify the ways in which doing good may help to counter the anxiety and depression that currently undermines the health and well-being of many people in all walks of life.", "And the need for kindness may have never been greater. The economic, educational and vocational stresses associated with the pandemic continue to take a toll. In addition, the media, the internet, and even neighborhood streets are often filled with physical threats and hateful remarks directed at large segments of the population.", "Although members of minority groups, be they racial, ethnic, religious or sexual, are increasingly willing to speak out against verbal and physical attacks and discrimination, many targeted individuals continue to suffer in silence. Little wonder that rates of anxiety and depression remain high.", "Children, who can readily sense the emotional distress of their caregivers, often share the pain. But experts say there\u2019s an antidote that could benefit everyone. They call it \u201cprosocial behavior,\u201d or acting in ways that help other people.", "In her recently published book, \u201cSocial Justice Parenting,\u201d Traci Baxley, an associate professor of education at Florida Atlantic University, emphasizes the rewards of teaching compassion and kindness to a new generation. Her goal in fostering a more just world for all is to raise children \u201cwho can ultimately self-advocate, empathize with others, recognize injustice, and become proactive in changing it.\u201d", "Her book, which I found hard to put down, is replete with excellent examples and advice that can help parents raise children with a healthy self-image and regard for the welfare of others. She wrote, \u201cIt is our obligation to teach our children to stand up and be allies for groups that are marginalized and silenced.\u201d", "Dr. Baxley, the mother of five children, told me that upon returning to school after the pandemic lockdown, many young people experienced an increase in depression and social anxiety that can be counteracted by prosocial behavior. \u201cJust seeing compassion and kindness in action releases chemicals in the brain that helps them calm down,\u201d she said. \u201cIt slows the heart rate and releases serotonin that counters symptoms of depression.\u201d", "Prosocial behavior may come naturally to some. Even children as young as 2 or 3 may spontaneously share a treat or toy with an unhappy playmate. But most children likely need to learn it from the same people who teach them to say \u201cplease\u201d and \u201cthank you,\u201d and the earlier in life that happens, the better.", "For starters, prosocial behavior requires compassion and empathy, the ability to recognize and care about the needs and well-being of others. But compassion without constructive follow-up benefits no one. Step two is kindness, a.k.a., compassion in action. You may be distressed to see an elderly person struggling with heavy packages, but unless you offer to help or at least express a wish to help but explain why you can\u2019t, your compassion goes to waste.", "One of my proudest moments as a grandmother was learning that a grandson, then in first grade, comforted a classmate who\u2019d become motion sick on a school bus trip. While other children on the bus moved away in disgust, my grandson put his arm on the ill child and asked if he felt better.", "As my four grandchildren continued to grow, I realized that all of them had too much \u201cstuff\u201d and I\u2019d been remiss by adding to the pile with my holiday gifts of toys and clothes. Henceforth, I told them, I would give them money to donate to any nonprofit group they choose that works to better the lives of others or the world. One boy picked a tutoring program for needy children; one chose an afterschool sports program; another with deep interest in the environment sent his gift to the American Forests; and the youngest, age 10, gave to a local food bank.", "Dr. Baxley recounts similar episodes in \u201cSocial Justice Parenting.\u201d She tells of a son\u2019s excitement at finding a $20 bill, then soon after giving it to an immigrant family holding a sign that read \u201cCan you please help us with our rent?\u201d", "Too often, Dr. Baxley said, parents place a higher value on getting good grades or winning at sports than on helping people who need it. She said it\u2019s also important to foster a child\u2019s emotional well-being by accepting and nurturing the child you have, not trying to forcefully create the one you want. A child who lacks athletic ability and spurns sports should not be made to participate in one because the parent values it and it could help the child get into college, she said.", "As a parent of biracial children and an educator, Dr. Baxley recognizes the challenges parents face when dealing with sensitive issues like race, disability, gender nonconformity and homelessness. But she urges parents not to let fear stand in the way of productive conversations. She maintains that even the most difficult topics, like racism, bullying, sexism and death, can be discussed sensitively and sincerely in terms that are age appropriate.", "Here are some of her suggestions.", "Instead of trying to find solutions for your children\u2019s concerns, she wrote, \u201clisten with the intent to hear and understand their feelings. Don\u2019t jump in and try to fix the issue or attempt to have the \u2018right\u2019 answers to their questions.\u201d", "You won\u2019t always know the right things to say, but it\u2019s important to acknowledge the child\u2019s feelings, avoid being critical, say what you think without judgment and invite feedback. For example, if your young child asks why a homeless person is so dirty, explain that the person has no home and no bathroom and perhaps even suggest making a donation of clothing or food to a homeless shelter.", "When dealing with major events and social justice issues, like an environmental catastrophe, the death of a loved one, police killing of Black people, or protests against injustice, strive to clarify misinformation. Perhaps read a book together that helps children deal with painful events, and discuss what action they might consider to mitigate the circumstances."]
